name: cobalt sulfate production | cobalt sulfate | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/25117/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg cobalt (II) sulfate (CoSO4), battery grade. Cobalt sulfate is used in storage batteries, especially in the production of the precursor of the cathode active material in NMC/NCA families Li-ion batteries. Values for materials and energy demand are estimated from the plant in Tongxiang, Zhejiang province (China) by Dai et al. (2018). The Tongxiang plant produces other cobalt products, such as Co3O4 and CoO, via further processing of refined CoSO4. These further processing steps involve the use of additional material and energy consumption, which were ascribed by the authors of the life cycle inventory (Dai et al., 2018) to battery-grade CoSO4 production because it was not possible to separate the material and energy requirements belonging to battery-grade CoSO4 production from those of the whole plant. Therefore, the data in this dataset represents a conservative estimate. Infrastructure has been included as well. ;Reference:;Dai, Q., C., K., & Elgowainy, A. (2018). Cobalt life cycle analysis update for the greet model (Tech. Rep.). Argonne, IL (United States): Argonne National Lab.(ANL).

The activity starts with cobalt hydroxide and other materials entering the factory.

The activity ends with the production of cobalt sulfate (CoSO4), battery grade, at factory gate.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is from 2018 (year of the publication of data) and 2020 (year of the dataset)
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Values are estimated from the production at the plant in Tongxiang, Zhejiang province (China) and assumed to be representative of the production process in China.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The process involves the treatment of cobalt hydroxide (Co(OH)2) with sulfuric acid (H2SO4) and disodium disulphite (Na2S2O5). The leached solution undergoes various precipitation steps to remove impurities. Evaporation and crystallization followed by filtration and  drying will produce battery-grade CoSO4 crystals.;Reference:;Dai, Q., C., K., & Elgowainy, A. (2018). Cobalt life cycle analysis update for the greet model (Tech. Rep.). Argonne, IL (United States): Argonne National Lab.(ANL).
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Data in the original publication (Dai et al. 2018. Cobalt life cycle analysis update for the greet model) refer to 1 ton Co eq. Conversion factor based on the ratio between the molecular weight of cobalt and cobalt sulfate was used. See comments to the exchanges for details.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value from Dai et al. (2018). Original value: 2.86 ton crude Co(OH)2/ton Co eq. Co MW = 58.933 g/mol; CoSo4 MW =  154.996 g/mol. Cobalt hydroxide is used in reaction with sulfuric acid to produce cobalt sulfate.
Crude Co(OH)2 is considered to have a cobalt content of 35%,  pure Co(OH)2 one of 63.4%

exchanges.description:
Calculated based on literature data published by the industry. For this activity, no information was readily available concerning infrastructure and land-use. Therefore, the infrastructure is estimated based on data from two chemical factories, the BASF site of Ludwigshafen and the chemical factory in Gendorf (which are both located in Germany), which produce a wide range of chemical substances. Based on this data, the following assumptions are made: the built area amounts to about 4.2 ha, the plant has an average output of 50'000 t/a and a lifespan of fifty years. The estimated infrastructure amount is therefore 4.00 E-10 units per kg of produced chemical. 
References: 
Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. ecoinvent report No. 8, v2.0. EMPA Dübendorf, Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, Dübendorf, CH. 
Gendorf (2000) Umwelterklärung 2000, Werk Gendorf. Werk Gendorf, Burgkirchen.om ecoinvent)

exchanges.description: Calculated value to get mass balance, based on stoichiometry. Water emissions from the reaction of Co(OH)2 + H2SO4 --> CoSO4 + 2H2O. The reaction involves a precipitation step, with separation between solid (cobalt sulfate) and liquid (water). CoSO4 MW = 154.996 g/mol; H2O MW = 18.015 g/mol.
Calculated value from Dai et al. (2018). Original value: 2.735 ton/ton Co eq. Co MW = 58.933 g/mol; CoSo4 MW =  154.996 g/mol.
